questions.text: The characteristic sail sign is due to the redundancy of the anterior tricuspid valve leaflet as shown below: This finding is associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ebstein anomaly Ebstein's anomaly is defined as the congenital displacement of the tricuspid valve towards the apex of the right ventricle, it is often associated with other abnormalities. In this, the first heart sound may be split and the second component of the first heart sound may have a distinctive snapping quality (known as the sail sign, due to the redundancy of the anterior tricuspid valve leaflet).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound. Option: C, D. NOT valvular involvement.

questions.text: Cyanotic congenital heart disease (CCHD) involves heart defects that reduce the amount of oxygen delivered to the rest of your body. It's sometimes called critical congenital heart disease. When a baby is born with CCHD, their skin has a bluish tint, called cyanosis. Which is the most common form of cyanotic congenital heart disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tetralogy of Fallot Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common form of cyanotic CHD, occurring in 0.5 per 1000 live births.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Less common than TOF. Option: C, D: Acyanotic congenital heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left ventricular hypertrophy Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) involves - Ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction, VSD, Right ventricular hypertrophy An overriding aorta.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, and D: These are classical components of TOF.

questions.text: The 1-year-old child presented with recurrent infections, breathing difficulty and cyanosis. Auscultation revealed a pan-systolic murmur of grade 5. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ventricular septal defect It is the most common congenital cardiac lesion identified at birth. VSD results in the shunting of oxygenated blood from the left to the right ventricle. The left ventricle starts contracting before the right ventricle; hence the murmur starts occurring early as pan systolic murmur and is palpable as a thrill.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . it is classified as fossa ovalis ASD, sinus venosus ASD, ostium primum ASD and coronary sinus ASD. The ejection systolic murmur occurs from the pulmonary valve due to increased blood flow. Delayed diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border and delayed P2 are heard. Option: C . A PDA courses between the aortic isthmus and the origin of one of the branch Pulmonary arteries. Small PDAs are often silent to auscultation and do not cause hemodynamic changes. The classic murmur is heard best just below the left clavicle and typically extends from systole past the second heart sound into diastole, reflecting flow turbulence and gradient between the aorta and the PAs (resulting in left-to-right shunting). Large PDAs will lead to left heart dilation and may lead to chronically elevated pulmonary vascular resistance, including the potential for ES. Option: D. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common form of cyanotic CHD. It involves anterior deviation of the Conal septum, resulting in RV outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction, a VSD, RV hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta

questions.text: A 1year old child has a history of recurrent infections, on auscultation a pan systolic murmur was heard. What is the most common site of the defect?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Membranous The most common location is in the membranous septum (also referred to as peri membranous or outlet defects).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. muscular defects are multiple and seen in the lower muscular part of the septum Option: C. Subpulmonary defects, also known as Conal septal defects, are commonly associated with prolapse of the right coronary cusp and aortic insufficiency. Option: D. Muscular defects that persist into adult life are often pressure and flow restricted, resulting in no significant hemodynamic consequence. AV canal defects also referred to as inlet defects, are located in the crux of the heart and are associated with abnormalities of the AV valve leaflets.

Extraedge:

Small muscular VSDs Large VSDs They have maximum chances of spontaneous closure.VSDs are the most common congenital anomaly recognized at birth, only a few cases of CHD are seen in the adult, due to the high rate of spontaneous closure of small VSDs during the early years of life. They usually cause symptoms of heart failure and poor somatic growth and are most often surgically closed before adulthood.

questions.text: 3 months old child with feeding difficulty, failure to thrive, cough and dyspnea. Auscultation reveals a case of ventricular septal defect. All are features commonly found in auscultation except:

options.label: B
options.text: pansystolic murmur in the left lower sternal border

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mid diastolic murmur MS: Carey-Coombs murmur (mid-diastolic apical murmur in acute rheumatic fever) Increased flow across Non-stenotic mitral valve (e.g., MR, PDA, high output states, and complete heart block) Tricuspid stenosis: Increased flow across nonstenotic tricuspid valve (e.g., TR, ASD, and anomalous pulmonary venous return) Left and right atrial tumours (myxoma) Severe AR (Austin Flint murmur) whereas Key Hodgkins is the primary murmur of AR. In VSD , delayed diastolic murmur occurs commonly due to an increased volume of blood passing through the mitral valve.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Holosystolic murmur is seen with Atrioventricular valve regurgitation (MR, TR) and Left-to-right shunt at ventricular level (VSD). The left ventricle starts contracting before the right ventricle; hence the murmur starts early occurring as pan systolic murmur and palpable as a thrill. Option: C. in VSD , the left ventricle has two outlets, the aortic valve being forward flow, and the septal defect being backward leak, it empties relatively early, leading to early A2. The ejection into the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery is increased because of the left to right shunt, and P2 is delayed, leading to widely split S2 Option: D. in VSD, the P2 is accentuated

questions.text: A child presented with cataract, microcephaly, mental retardation and deafness. Systemic examination revealed VSD. What could be the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital rubella syndrome Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by the presence of fetal cardiac malformations (especially patent ductus arteriosus and ventricular septal defect), eye lesions (especially cataracts), microcephaly, mental retardation and deafness.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. it is an autosomal dominant condition with TBX 5 mutation that presents with radial ray anomalies, ostium secundum ASD and VSD Option: B. Fetal alcohol syndrome presents with microcephaly and mental retardation. Cardiac involvement includes atrial septal defect and ventricular septal defect Option: D. Noonan syndrome presents with short stature, dysmorphic facies, webbed neck and cryptorchidism is an autosomal dominant condition due to mutation in PTPN11. Cardiac manifestations are ASD, pulmonic stenosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Extraedge:

Rubella presents with malaise, fever, mild conjunctivitis and lymphadenopathy . Small petechial lesions on the soft palate ( Forchheimer spots) are suggestive. Congenital Rubella Syndrome transmission occurs in the first trimester mainly. The eruptive or exanthematous phase usually occurs within 7 days of the initial symptoms. The rash first appears on the forehead and then spreads to involve the trunk and limbs. It is pinkish-red, macular and discrete, although some of these lesions may coalesce. It usually fades by the second day and rarely persists beyond 3 days after its appearance. Maternal infection in pregnancy may result in congenital rubella syndrome. Rubella affects the fetuses of up to 90% of all women who contract the infection during the first trimester of pregnancy. The incidence of congenital abnormalities diminishes in the second trimester and no ill- effects result from infection in the third trimester.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with cleft palate, nasal regurgitation, recurrent infections and learning difficulties. H/o convulsions in the neonatal period. Family H/o was present. The cardiac defects associated with this condition are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ASD The features are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome: CATCH 22 or DiGeorge syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition with a microdeletion in 22q. Presents with cleft palate, convulsions due to hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia leading to recurrent infections, nasal regurgitation, gastroesophageal reflux and learning disability. Cardiac manifestations are Interrupted aortic arch, tetralogy of Fallot, ventricular septal defect, persistent truncus arteriosus, and double outlet right ventricle. DiGeorge syndrome is an inheritable chromosomal disorder.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In ventricular septal defect, the most common site involved is membranous, VSD present with loud pansystolic murmur with palpable thrill, delayed diastolic murmur, loud P2 and widely split S2. Option: C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common form of cyanotic CHD. It involves anterior deviation of the conal septum, resulting in RV outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction, a VSD, RV hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta Option: D. it is a rare congenital cyanotic heart disease characterized by a single truncal valve, single ventricular outflow tract and VSD. It presents with an ejection click and systolic murmur. Irreversible severe pulmonary hypertension occurs.

questions.text: A ventricular septal defect is a hole in the heart, that is a common heart defect that's present at birth. The hole (defect) occurs in the wall (septum) that separates the heart's lower chambers and allows blood to pass from the left to the right side of the heart. Features of nonrestrictive VSD are all except:

options.label: B
options.text: Present with heart failure in childhood

options.label: C
options.text: Size less than 25% of aortic root diameter

questions.correct_answer: C. Size less than 25% of aortic root diameter
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Size less than 25% of aortic root diameter VSD sizes are defined by comparison to the aortic root size; small or restrictive VSD - < 25% of the aortic root diameter, moderately restrictive VSD - 25–75% of the aorta, unrestricted VSD - > 75% of the aortic diameter. Because of its larger diameter, blood can flow freely without any restriction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. in large nonrestrictive VSD, a large volume of blood shunts into the pulmonary vasculature leading to the remodelling of vessels and pulmonary hypertension. Eventually, right ventricular pressure supersedes left, and flow starts from right to the left causing cyanosis known as Eisenmenger syndrome Option: B. large unrestrictive VSD present with heart failure in childhood leading to pulmonary hypertension and Eisenmenger syndrome Option: D. Qp/Qs ratio Restrictive lesion being less than 1.5:1, Moderately restrictive VSD being 1.5–2.2:1, Unrestricted lesion being greater than 2.2:1.
